ray.rage.scene

Interface SceneNode

  • All Superinterfaces:
    Managed<SceneManager>, Nameable, Node
    All Known Implementing Classes:
    GenericSceneNode

    public interface SceneNode
extends Node, Managed<SceneManager>
    A scene node is a node used as the basis for a tree-based scene graph data structure, allowing scene-objects to be attached to the scene nodes.

    Scene nodes are created and managed by a scene-manager and may be aware of a scene-manager's space partitioning schemes, if any.

    Author:
    Raymond L. Rivera
    See Also:
    SceneObject

    • Method Detail

      • createChildSceneNode

        SceneNode createChildSceneNode(java.lang.String childName)
        Creates a new child for this scene-node.

        Since scene-nodes are aware of the manager that created them, implementations use SceneManager.createSceneNode(String) when instantiating children. This allows the manager to remain aware of all the scene-nodes.

        Parameters:
        childName - A unique name for the child.
        Returns:
        A new scene-node.
        Throws:
        java.lang.IllegalArgumentException - If the name is empty.
        java.lang.RuntimeException - If the name is already in use.
        java.lang.NullPointerException - If the name is null.

      • notifyRootNode

        void notifyRootNode()
        Notifies this scene-node that it is the root node.

        WARNING: This method is meant to be used internally by the framework and not by game clients. Only the scene-manager should use this.

        Throws:
        java.lang.RuntimeException - If this scene-node has a parent.

      • attachObject

        void attachObject(SceneObject so)
        Attaches a scene-object to this scene-node.

        The scene-node is responsible for notifying the scene-object that it just got attached by invoking its SceneObject.notifyAttached(SceneNode) method.

        Parameters:
        so - The scene-object being attached.
        Throws:
        java.lang.RuntimeException - If the scene-object is already attached.
        java.lang.NullPointerException - If the scene-object is null.

      • getAttachedObject

        SceneObject getAttachedObject(java.lang.String name)
        Gets the named scene-object attached to this scene-node.
        Parameters:
        name - The name of the attached scene-object.
        Returns:
        The scene-object attached.
        Throws:
        java.lang.RuntimeException - If the specified scene-object is not attached.

      • getAttachedObject

        SceneObject getAttachedObject(int index)
        Gets the specified scene-object attached to this scene-node.
        Parameters:
        index - The position of the attached scene-object.
        Returns:
        The scene-object attached, if any.
        Throws:
        java.lang.IndexOutOfBoundsException - If the index is outside the [0, getAttachedObjectCount()) range.

      • getAttachedObjectCount

        int getAttachedObjectCount()
        Gets the number of scene-objects attached to this scene-node.
        Returns:
        The number of currently attached scene-objects.

      • getAttachedObjects

        java.lang.Iterable<SceneObject> getAttachedObjects()
        Gets an Iterable of attached scene-objects.
        Returns:
        The Iterable.

      • detachObject

        void detachObject(SceneObject so)
        Detaches the scene-object from this scene-node.

        The scene-node is responsible for notifying the scene-object that it just got detached by invoking SceneObject.notifyDetached().

        Parameters:
        so - The scene-object to be detached.
        Throws:
        java.lang.NullPointerException - If the specified scene-object is null.
        java.lang.RuntimeException - If the specified scene-object is not attached.

      • detachObject

        SceneObject detachObject(java.lang.String name)
        Detaches the scene-object from this scene-node.

        The scene-node is responsible for notifying the scene-object that it just got detached by invoking SceneObject.notifyDetached().

        Parameters:
        name - The name of the scene-object to detach.
        Returns:
        The scene-object that has been detached.
        Throws:
        java.lang.RuntimeException - If the specified scene-object is not attached.

      • detachAllObjects

        void detachAllObjects()
        Detaches all the scene-objects from this scene-node, without destroying them.

        The scene-node is responsible for notifying all scene-objects that they just got detached by invoking their SceneObject.notifyDetached() method.

      • notifyInSceneGraph

        void notifyInSceneGraph(boolean inGraph)
        Notifies this scene-node whether it's in the scene graph or not.

        A scene-node is in the scene graph when there's an unbroken link between this scene-node all the way to its ultimate ancestor, the root scene-node.

        WARNING: This method is meant to be used internally by the framework and not by game clients. Use directly only if you really know what you're doing.

        Parameters:
        inGraph - True if this scene-node is in the scene graph. Otherwise false.

      • isInSceneGraph

        boolean isInSceneGraph()
        Checks whether this scene-node is in the scene graph or not.

        A scene-node is in the scene graph when there's an unbroken link between this scene-node all the way to its ultimate ancestor, the root scene-node.

        Returns:
        True if this scene-node is in the scene graph. Otherwise false.
